awd_titl_txt: CNS Core: Small: Bridging the Silos of Edge Computing with Connected Namespaces
awd_abstract_narration:
Edge computing provides opportunities to process data closer to its sources, on computing elements embedded in the data network path. It can be transformative for many important classes of latency-sensitive and data-intensive applications, such as Smart City, autonomous systems and transportation, augmented and virtual reality (AR/VR), visual analytics, etc. However, realizing the potential benefit of edge computing is not trivial, because it relies on the ability to make timely decisions across diverse resources and services, disaggregated across many siloed providers, and governed by dynamically changing operating conditions. For applications seeking benefits from edge computing, this presents challenges in obtaining the right set of available resources. For stakeholders contributing resources to edge computing, this presents challenges in maintaining desired degree of control over their resources. To address this problem, this project develops a new Decentralized Edge Exchange that builds on a new system-level abstraction, called connected namespaces, to enable dynamic, fine-grained, and cross-stakeholder resource orchestrations in edge computing. Importantly, the exchange natively integrates use of tailored cryptographic techniques, namely, multi-party computation (MPC), to achieve full privacy while meeting all the real-time performance requirements of the complete system. 
 
The technologies developed in this project permit edge computing applications to utilize the best available edge resources, even when those are fragmented across and owned by multiple parties, while still providing each stakeholder with controls regarding their resource use and sharing policies. The ability to deliver on performance without sacrificing confidentiality and controls removes critical concerns about edge computing, which otherwise hamper its adoption. As a result, this research presents a path for future developments in the new edge infrastructure tier, support for important classes of emerging applications, new execution platforms comprising novel hardware and software technologies for the edge, and catalyzes the adoption of edge computing as a new source of revenue streams and economic growth.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Edge computing, or the use of resources at or near the end-points, at the network edges, is becoming an additional key component of the end-to-end service infrastructure. It can deliver transformational benefits to many emerging classes of applications seeking low and predictable latency and/or requiring large movements of data, requirements that cannot be efficiently met with cloud datacenter-based service deployments. However, realizing the potential benefit of edge computing is not trivial, because it relies on the ability to make timely decisions across silos of diverse, disaggregated and dynamic resources. 

The research conducted under this project addresses these limitations by developing new and efficient multi-stakeholder edge services for resource discovery, management and allocation; integrating support for fine-grained management of security and privacy using Multi-Party Computation- (MPC-) based cryptographic techniques; and developing driving use-cases for edge computing services and applications. 

The intellectual merit of this research comprises new system technologies, protocols and security mechanisms that will allow for timely, performant, and secure cross-stakeholder services and resource orchestrations in edge computing. This enables deployment of new classes of edge applications across the best  available edge resources, while still providing each stakeholder with full privacy guarantee and control of their resource use and sharing policies. Concrete outcomes of the research include Angler, a first ever system that enables MPC-based resource allocation in distributed/decentralized edge systems with only 2x runtime overhead without revealing any providers’ secret data; edge-native services for resource discovery (MEC-CDN) and resource management (ShapeShifter), with up to an order-of-magnitude improved latency compared to cloud-native solutions; new hardware features and acceleration opportunities that can further advance the practical application of MPC- based techniques; and a suite of representative benchmarks for MEC, including for emerging applications such as AR/XR.  

The broader impacts of this research are achieved through dissemination of technical results to the research community, via publications and presentations at international conferences and industry events, students’ PhD dissertations, open source software and benchmarks, and through student training.
